reviewText:
When I first heard of Mars: War Logs, I was... skeptical. Not that the idea of a cyberpunk RPG set on Mars didn't appeal to me. And other reviews had made it sound sort of average at best. Yet I'm not one to reject new ideas and so I decided to give it a shot. And it was only around twenty bucks.
To put it bluntly: money well spent.
Mars: War Logs is a pretty intense game, with a tight storyline and at least decent gameplay. Sure, its graphics don't have a prayer against the latest incarnation of CoD and the like, but they are pretty impressive on their own for an indie game.
You play as Roy Temperance, prisoner in a POW camp on Mars, in the aftermath of a war between two rival factions veering for dominance over the planet. The game begins with you saving a young man named Innocence from becoming a 'punk' and from thereon planning your escape from the camp.
(For some reason I have yet to discern, every man in this setting is named after a virtue, Innocence, Temperance, Constance, Prudence... weird. But not bad. Roy is actually the odd man out in this scenario.)
This is an action-rpg, meaning your character, Roy, is already a somewhat badass mofo, and the rpg-elements only serve to give you a choice what kind of badass mofo you're going to be. It follows the standard fighter-mage-thief trinity, with fighter being self explanatory, thief being labeled stealth and covering also things like fast-talking and bartering, and magic being called technomancy. I don't want to spoil anything but you have to progress a while in the game to acquire the technomancy abilities.
There is a karma meter that influences what kind of perks you get, which influence your style of badass mofo-ery. You in turn influence the karma meter (or reputation) by your actions, specifically whether or not you extract water units from dead bodies. Extracting the water is bad, by the way.
There is also a crafting system that allows you to create health or mana potions, or to upgrade your weapons and armor. What I actually like is that the upgrades also have a visual effect on Roy. You only fight with melee weapons for most of time, but in best prison tradition you can turn a simple rod into the shiv to end all shivs.

One thing I have to say though: I think cyberpunk is not really the best way to describe the game. For me the game was more like a dirtier, grittier version of the Dune novels and the David Lynch movie. But maybe that's just me.

Okay, bottom line: for an indie game, Mars: War Logs is pretty damn good. Sure, it cannot compare to the works of Bioware, Obsidian and Bethesda, but that is not the point. On its own merits, it works perfectly. I really recommend checking it out, because for twenty bucks you will get a lot more bang, so to speak.

reviewText:
It is clear that this game has been cut short of its full vision. However, in this case, this isn't a bad thing.

The game feels fairly focused and doesn't give me that sense of dread that some larger aRPGs give you. The feeling that this is going to take FOREVER to get through. There are your typical fetch quests and needless backtracking, but the three main hubs are smallish and easy to navigate.

The current translation and VO is perfectly acceptable. Then again, I thought E.Y.E's translation was serviceable.

The atmosphere in this game is wonderful. There is also some great model work and texture work.

For a cheap price, a taught little aRPG that can be knocked out in a weekend.

reviewText: Mars War Logs is what you would get if you made Fallout using the the game mechanics of Knights of the Old Republic. The game is fun, and has a few moments of really well done story. The Dialog is both really good and really bad, depending on the character. Innocence (strange heavy handied naming convention asside) Is a great character and the airy voice acting does wonders to enhance the character. The main character however is totally hit or miss, mostly because it's obvious the lines weren't read in order, so he reacts strangly or puts odd emphasis on lines.\n\nIf you need a TLDR, the worst thing I could say for this game is it's a bit unpollished. There are no big bugs that I've seen, but the game's a bit short, thin, and mediocre, when compared to the Bethesda and Bioware counteparts that are the obvious influences. All that said It's a good game, with a good story, and I'm enjoying it.

reviewText:
Mars: Wars Logs

Description:
An indie/rpg style game. Set on a post-apocalyptic Mars, your character is thrown into a power struggle between factions. The atmosphere sort of reminds me of a steampunky dune, complete with electric magic, sneaky face-whacking, political backstabbing, a bit of romance, and even a sandworm!

Pros:
The atmosphere is interesting. Drab, desert-ish industrial themes, with little splashes of color or variation.
The commerce system is simple, but effective. You can buy ingredients to construct upgrades to weapons and armor, or scavenge them from the environment.
The combat system is different from anything else I've used, but easy to get the hang of. The first chapter is a bit slow, and gives you plenty of time to get your bearings before throwing you into the thick of it.
The general plot and main characters are interesting enough, but some of the voice acting (especially for minor characters) is less than stellar, and in a few cases, downright bad.
The perk trees are nicely done. Basic, but they allow you to tailor your approach to combat to suit your style of play. The perks come in three trees, Stealth, Ranged Attacks and Healing, Manual Combat, or Technomancy (magic). Each tree has a few tiers of perks that unlock as you purchase items in that string, and each perk has three upgradeable layers of effectiveness.
Cons:
The visuals are drab, and this can make it a bit hard to navigate, simply because you're visually bored.
The side quests can be too vague. I had to resort to a walk-through for one in particular...turned out I had already missed my opportunity to complete the task.
It's a damn short game. I took my time, and it only took me 10 hours to complete.
The alignment system is janky. It makes some actions (ex. harvesting serum from downed enemies) obviously bad"
date: but it doesn't give you any direction or input as to how to navigate these choices or check your progress. I made "good" choices all the way through
recommended: and still finished the game with a "neutral" alignment
hoursPlayed: preventing me from taking advantage of the various perks attached to either of the divergent character paths.\n\nOverall
voteText: a good diversion RPG game
helpfulPercent: to play in between titles like Skyrim and Mass Effect. Maybe not worth $15
votesHelpful: but I'd recommend buying it when it's on sale."

reviewText:
Good buy, good game! I was in the mood for Fallout however I am not a big fan of replaying games I have already beat. I wanted something new with a post apocalyptic/science fiction style game with RPG elements and plot twists that will keep me interested. Mars: War Logs is a good vacation into that craving. Not as good as a Fallout however has some similar elements that I enjoy. If Fallout 3/New Vegas slept with Star Wars KOTR 1 & 2 and had a baby, and the doctor accidentally dropped it on its head than it would be Mars: War Logs. They do some really good things right in this game, I enjoy the combat system more than I thought I would, the crafting system is simply yet still has me looking everywhere for items to craft.

It has story line tasks while providing a little smaller tasks to keep you busy. The controls are easy and quick to pick up. The characters are well done with solid voice overs to help you follow along. I am only 3 hours into this game and will play it until I beat it. I do wish it was more open world like Fallout as the first chapter keeps you rather confined to a KOTR style area. Maybe as I get closer to the end it will open up more however that is really my only complaint. For what I paid for the game it was well worth my money. I am surprised however that this game did not get more attention than it has as it I have played more hyped games with worst design than this one. If I was to give it a star rating 1-5 I would say this is an easy 3 1/2 stars, 5 being the best. I will continue to dig deeper and this is well worth your time and money.

Thanks for reading,
Ice

reviewText:
In the distant future, mankind has finally colonized the red planet that is Mars.
But something happened that threw the entire planet along with the colonists into chaos and now water has become the most valuable and sought after resource, a few companies are starting wars over this resource.
Now it is nearly a century after the cataclysmic event and you play as Roy, a renegade who has spent some time at a prisoner of war camp when the arrival of a new prisoner by the name of Innocence changes everything for him.
After saving Innocence from a rather nasty fate in the showers, he agrees to help Roy with escaping the camp and so begins the tale of Mars: War Logs.
The combat in this game is really good, it is in some ways similar to The Witcher's combat system and feels fluid.
You can also gather various materials from crates, heaps of junk and more that you can use to craft new armor and attachments to any of your moddable weapons.
A must have for those who enjoy a good cyberpunk RPG.

reviewText:
As an indie game, I find the rating of Mars: War Logs unfair.
I admit I played the game just now, as of January 2015. I have no idea of how bugged it was - apparently it was, according to other reviewers - but in my hands ran just smoothly.
Based on such remarks, here are my opinions on the game:

The setting and the artwork are nice, with a flavour of steam-punk style. After all, Mars is the red planet.
Dungeons, caves, and maps in general are a bit repetitive.
Dialogues are just fine. Perhaps they lack a bit of depth, though they are just enjoyable as such. The story is nice and leaves plenty of room for other episodes.
Animations are well made. It is nice the way it slows time down when opening the wheel menu or while counter-attacking.
It is a pity that jumping is not available, although it would be useless considering the game mechanics.
RPG mechanics are OK; the characters evolves by spending points in the three branches or potentiating already unlocked skills.
Combat may be the weak element of the game. After getting acquainted with the commands and the combat mechanics, the most successful way is to evade all the time, hit'n'run. If AoE skills from the Technomancer's branch, that becomes even easier.
Equipment is also lacking depth. There is a lot of different weapon and armour upgrades, though it is rather difficult to find upgradable pieces during the game. The nice point here, is that you can adjust your gameplay by choosing the desired upgrades - which, by the way, also change parts of the look of the upgraded item according to their stats.
Crafting also appears to be incomplete and could be improved a lot.

Overall, I believe this is not a < 60 game". As already state
recommended: I would rate this as a 65
hoursPlayed: at least."
voteText: February 1, 2015

reviewText:
I was hesitant at first about this game. It's worth every penny.

The game is a mix of gameplay from Dragon Age and any MMORPG. It takes place on Mars, with 3 long chapters, and allows you to have one party member at one time. You only focus on your characters items and skills, the game handles the rest.

The game takes roughly 8 hours, including all side quests. This has a moderate replay value so you definitely find yourself wanting to change your choices the second time around. There are minor kinks that need to be worked out, but not very noticeable.

4/5. Great game.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved this game. I am a sucker for anything sci-fi, and the concept and story were extremely intriguing to me.

Are there a couple of rough edges to the game? Yes. Should you be impressed nonetheless considering this was made by such a small studio? I think so.

I feel I've read some reviews claiming this is just a boring, linear hack and slash. I have no idea what they are talking about. I just beat it on Extreme difficulty, and I constantly had to plan out what enemy among the group I would need to take down first, throwing dust in one's eyes, wounding one of their melee fighters with a nailgun to slow him down, and then pound on their technomancer so I wouldn't be turned into fried chicken. Some of the battles I won almost soley out of luck.

Anyway, I think the game is great. As I write this, it's only $3.74 on Steam. This may be one of the best valued purchases I've made this year.

reviewText: You're Roy, a soldier for Aurora, one of the two guilds that wrestle for controll over the scarce supply of water on the red planet. Captured by Abundance, you plan your escape along with a fellow prisoner named Innocence. Along the way you meet the rag-tags of the slum, the underground resistance fighting for freedom and a power crazed group called the technomancers.\n\nVery enjoyable game, despite some of the voice acting being on the odd side. The world reacts to the moral choices of your character, and despite having no definite class system beyond three skill trees, the game has a high replay value.

reviewText:
A 3rd person, post apocalyptic, sci-fi, RPG, only second to tittles such as The Witcher series and Mass Effect(back when it still was good).

It has a similar combat feeling to that of The Witcher 2, the map design on the other hand is more linear and maze-like.

The only real flaws this game has it's its not so good voice acting and the story sadly feels a little short/rushed towards the end. But taking in consideration it is a budget game and not an AAA title, it is more than well done!
It's few flaws are easily shadowed by a good story overall, solid and refreshing lore, interesting character development, interesting companions, and high variety of customization and upgrades for both weapons and armors alike.

For only 20 bucks(release price) is a must buy if you enjoy good RPGs! And at a discount pirce it is a steal!
Definitely not an investment you will likely regret!

reviewText:
Hidden gem of a game.  Not quite as polished as some other action/RPG games but it has a really interesting background story and deserves more coverage than it has.  It is quite a short game but I was compelled to complete the side missions and play through to the end.

Deserves a playthrough by any fan of the genre & definitely deserves a sequel.

reviewText:
Nice, solid, little rough round the edges RPG.
It's like one of those hidden jems you pick up at the book exchange. You read the back cover and decide its worth a dollar or two but dont expect much. What you end up getting is a fantastic story, great characters and fantastic atmosphere.

Sure the books pretty short and the cover and spine (gameplay) is barely held together but by the end you're glad you found it. You might even recommend it to someone down the track.

That is what Mars: War Logs felt to me. Also bonus points for a sandworm bossfight.

reviewText: I spent a lot of time during combat in this game rolling on the ground ocassionally getting up to whack someone with a pipe or stick...after a while I could zap them!...and everything was rusty, grimey, and rusty-orange. Those were my major memories of Mars:War Logs. The name is not quite apt...Mars:Rusty and Grimey perhaps. If it was a movie the  word to describe Mars:War Logs would be slight" and reviewers would be politely disparaging if they only watched Holywood blockbusters. Not to be too negative though- the game is a primarily fun with a reasonably interesting if short and slightly predictable story. Character development and voice acting are decent for a video game. The RPG elements are rather of the "Witcher" variety but the game lacks  the "Witcher" depth and polish. But it isn't bad just short and ordinary. Replayability is limited in my opinion but given the cost what does one expect."

reviewText:
Pros:

Cons:

reviewText:
Mars: War Logs was a pretty interesting game. I purchased this during it's 75% off sale and I can say that it was worth the money spent, but had I bought this game for full price, even at the low price it is already at, I would have felt a little bummed out, but not enough to really regret the purchase.

The flaws in this game are few, but affect the immersion and gameplay pretty heavily. For starters, we have the most obvious issue of poor lip synching for the voice overs and poor voice actors. Now, I don't know about you, but when it comes to a game made in 2013, you'd think that you could at least have proper lip synching so that your game characters don't look like a bunch of puppets when they talk.

The voice acting side of things in this game also comes with another tag along flaw of horribly bad dialog and just general sloppyness of a story. It has a nice twist in the beginning which is refreshing when it comes to your main character, but that is about it. The voice actors in this game were not refreshing however...and at times, even right off in the beginning they showed their lack of skill at voice acting. This could have also been a result of poor direction as well, which would be understandable, but it's still significant enough that on my first playthrough I was skipping the dialog just so I didn't have to suffer.

Companion choices are obvious enough that you won't be surprised at all and the game does have you do a fair bit of running around for quests, which gets annoying at times, but not so much as to detract from the gameplay a whole lot. The game is extremely linear and I also felt that your reputation in the game meant all of ♥♥♥♥ when it comes down to it. My reputation was bad the entire time and it didn't affect anything I could percieve to be a detriment to my gameplay when it came to companion interaction or affecting the story. The only thing it did affect was that I couldn't get the companion bonus feat or the merchant price reduction, but that wasn't a big deal considering my companion was only good for distracting an enemy or two and that the game gives you everything in the game that you need. Vendors were pretty much pointless as a whole and the crafting system, while neat, was generally pointless as well as once you obtain the copper tube and leather outfit in the 2nd chapter you effectively have the best weapon and armor in the game.

Combat is frustrating but fun, and stealth is a broken mechanic allowing you to typically take out 1-2 baddies before they notice you. Explosives are your friend and the blast power with the cone effect is really the only power I ever used since the shield and weapon powers take forever to cast.

The best thing about this game is the detail in the environments. This game looks gritty and dirty and it's great.

I was expecting more, but for the price I paid I knew that I wasn't going to be super impressed with it, however I didn't hate it and if you are looking for a cheap game to beat then pick this one up during a sale.

reviewText:
8/10 - A gem in the rough.

If you love the Witcher 2, you'll enjoy this one. This game seems to have closely watched and learned from that game. Although somewhat short (about 12 hours while also doing side quests), this game has the making of something great. The world and characters are intriguing, although the game is a tad too short to really flesh it out. The combat could use some tweaks here and there, as there are big difficulty spikes: once you're comfortable with one class of enemy, a significantly tougher one is introduced. This is fine, except for the fact that these tougher enemies come in packs of at least 4, which can be overwhelming until you upgrade your gear.

Would love to see more from this IP in the future, preferably a tad longer and with some more polishing.

One of the common gripes I can see in other reviews is the combat system. It's much different from what I have seen in most other RPGs, and I would say that it's challenging to master. In fact the difficulty level of some battles seems to be quite inconsistent, as I don't remember having many problems fighting my enemies in latter stages of the game (except for a boss fight in the latter portion of the game, which featured a completely unique type of enemy), but some battles in the beginning were frustrating and at times overwhelmingly difficult. reviewText:
Mars: War Logs is a game which truly represents the Icarian myth of aiming high but falling because of it’s ambitions. This isn’t to say this game is a complete write-off as I’m still playing it and enjoying it… most of the time. As I play it, I feel that the developers have taken great ideas from other games and then mashed them together, without fully developing any of them. The leveling up is based on experience gain and allows you to spent points on perks (like Fallout), and separate points on skills with a skill tree reminiscent of The Witcher 2. Though unlike The Witcher 2, there’s not real room for focus on one particular skill set as you need to utilise everything at your disposal such as dodging, blocking, attacking, traps, bombs, guns, technomancy (magic), healing and other party members to be able to survive through most combats. Because you need all of these, you need to spread your skill points evenly across the board. Though I will say that the skills have significant effects on what your character can do, as do the perks, meaning that your choice in either do matter.

Mars: War Logs aspires to be a lot of things, though doesn’t quite reach any of them. This all being said, this blog is called Icarus Reviews and I cannot fault a game too much for aiming high, even if it doesn’t succeed.

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/03/14/mars-war-logs/

reviewText:
First off I'll get the problems out of the way. The game can be a little buggy but nothing show stopping. The mechanics of the game, how the fighting system works and so on, not perfect but I'm not all about game mechanics. Take a game like Jade Empire, it's flawed mechanically but there's so much more to that game, it's great fun. This game is very much like that too. Jade Empire, Remember me, games like that are more about telling a story and the RPG elements and game mechanics are there to keep you interested while that story plays out.

I don't like Mars: War Logs, I absolutely love it. Good science fiction tales are hard to come by in PC gaming and this is very much one of them. I'm also gobsmacked that such a small developer was able to pull off so much. So for me it helped a lot that I went into this game knowing a fair bit about the developers, what they were trying to do and forgave the problems the game has because of that.

Take a game like Skyrim. A truly epic game with a massive budget and huge team of programmers  and artists. Even that game has many problems but I adore that game despite its problems. I love that they were trying to create a huge open world and fill that world with enough content, that at times it felt like I was in a real place, really role playing my way through it. Mars: War Logs is trying to do the same but with a tiny fraction of the budget of Skyrim. The fact there were plenty of times I also felt I was in another place, really role playing my way through it is quite astounding to me.

Bottom line, if you love a good Sci-Fi tale and want to be immersed into it, this game will give you that. On sale it's an absolute steal and a must have. At full price, I'd say you probably should avoid if this is going into a backlog to be played later as it will go on sale again. If you want to play it right now, the full price which is £11.99 as of writing this, I'd pay that.

reviewText: If you don't mind some mid-quality voice acting, some stiff animations, and a bit of odd lighting, there is an enjoyable, tacticle, hack'n'slash RPG here.  Clocking at about 12 hours, MWL is a game full of action, loot, upgrades, crafting, exploration, and dialog choices that affect the outcome of the story.  It maddens me that games like this get dumped on in the reviews.  It's clearly made by people who love what they do, and their aim is to entertain.  Not every movie is Star Wars, people.  Not every band is Pink Floyd.  Not every video game is Fallout 3 or Mass Effect.  This game's rough edges give it that charming underground indie band feeling, and I loved just about every minute of it.  Give me fifty titles just like this before giving me ONE Call of Duty.  Could this game have somehow possibly been better?  Sure, but so could your mom last night, but she's still worth paying for.  ZING!

reviewText: Mars: War Logs is quite an interesting play. The gameplay reminded me of KOTOR, while the overall story was unique and a bit refreshing. The equipment in the game is fitting, if limited. However, the upgrades are what makes the gear. I felt a bit limited by the linear story, but there was enough detail in the extra info to help flush out the story some. The dialogue was probably the worst part of the game, which did limit me from really -liking- any particular character. I also didn't feel that following a good/bad path really affected the game all that much.\n\nOverall, Mars: War Logs just missed the bar from being an excellent game. However, if you are a scifi/rpg fan, I highly recommend giving it a playthrough.

reviewText:
Score: 6.5/10
Similar Games
Red Faction Guerrilla, Demonicon, E.Y.E Devine Cybermancy

Summary
You are Roy. A prisoner of a war that is just about to be over. After coming to the aid of a boy named Innoscence you begin to gather up forces for an escape. The game has a reputation system and some perks are based off reputation. Besides the perks you also have access to three different skill trees. Gather up scrap to upgrade armor and weapons. You will also be creating nail gun ammo and kits. The real reason Roy wishes to escape he keeps to himself until the time is right.

The Good
The combat is actually good. Just remember that if you kill enemies to get serum they respawn depending on the area and enemy. I never tested sneak in the game so I can't speak on if that works well or not. The guns, weapons, and technomancer combos are pretty fun and very solidly implemented. The armor & weapon upgrade system looks freakin awesome and allows for quite a bit of a custom look even if there is essentially only two base armor looks to start from. The backstory on the world is pretty interesting.

The Bad
Back and forth...back and forth.... back and forth... back and forth... The game makes you travel like constantly and when you reach the end of the first city you will be utterly sick of it. The loads tend to freeze up a little bit from time to time in the city area. The only monster enemies is the moles, and other then that its basically three types of human enemies. The game does endlessly reuse tiles, but that is a minor problem since they reuse them smartly. The story in the game doesn't really stand up to the awesome backstory of the world.

Conclusion
Honestly this game was probably a bit to ambitious for such a low budget small studio, but the games got a good heart to it. The Mad Max without the vehicles feel the game presents is pretty awesome to boot.

Value
The game by default is only $15, but I'd probably suggest waiting until its 50% off before going for it.

reviewText: I am enjoying this game a whole lot so far. I have read some bad reviews about this game which I feel are unfair. The only gripe is that the animations are a bit clunky and some of the dialog doesn't always make complete sense; however this has been on rare occassions.  Once you can see past that this is a very indepth story driven game with some very cool features. The graphics and sound are good. The combat system is very strategic. All in all this is a very good game. If you are unsure wait until it is in the sale. If you like indepth RPGS and are not expecting AAA then you will probably really enjoy this game. I think it is very polished except for the animations and the odd camera issue. Nothing terrible here. Pros outway the cons by a long shot. 8/10.

reviewText:
If MST3K existed for videogames, this would be a shoe-in.  Massively ambitious, flawed in numerous ways but with a charm very much of its own.  Veers from cringeworthy awfulness (the romance subplot...) to moments of real poignance.  Whatever you might think of the execution, you certainly can't accuse the devs of not trying...

Fingers crossed their next effort, The Technomancer, will have some of M:WL's more painfully rough edges smoothed off, and a layer of polish applied.  Fingers also crossed though, that there'll be enough outright weirdness left afterwards to make that game as strangely compelling as this one.

One for the brave, the masochistic and the jaded!

reviewText:
The story takes place in the distant future on Mars. Long ago in the history of the game Mars was a prosperous colony on a well terraformed world. Now it is something of a post apocalypse wasteland where the surviving remnants of civilization fight over continually dwindling resources. People known as Psychers use ancient technology to manifest magic like abilities serving as elite military personnel for the factions.

The protagonist of the game is a renegade Psycher who becomes embroiled in a plot to stop the Psychers from one of the factions from completing a secret project and taking control over society for their own mysterious ends. The story begins in a military prison from which the hero escapes with a comrade, then moves to a neighboring empire where you either ally with a band of idealistic rebels or a concerned faction of the establishment to stop the Psycher plot.

Game play is two pronged. There is a branching story to navigate and you can form alliances with different factions and relationships with different potential allies. There are also various side quests to occupy your time. This shares about equal footing with the hand to hand combat encounters which are a mix of arcade action and leveling/gearing your character in various combat powers and attributes.

The storytelling and world building are the game's strongest selling points. Unfortunately both suffer a little from uneven writing in the dialog and plotting. At times the story can be quite compelling, especially in the game's first two chapters. As it moves on things get a bit more predictable and wrote and the end of the game is on the anti-climactic side. The same goes for the world building. It starts out very intriguing but before too long you realize you are only going to scratch the surface of it while playing the game.

The combat and character building are lackluster but not deficient. Most of the combat choices are decent and they do lead to different tactics during fights. The controls are a little on the awkward side and the combat animations are not the sophisticated sort you find in Witcher 3 or the Batman games. It is a pretty simple game with fairly simple mechanics.

Ultimately it feels like a game made by professionals but both a bit behind the times and on a very limited budget. The locations are linear and limited and the range of enemies is pretty small. There is a fair bit of detail in the art, but there isn’t all that much of it. I certainly got my moneys worth and personally I like a short game with a concise story. By the time it had started to show its weaknesses the game was nearly over.

I recommend it for fans of the genre so long as you go in wanting a smaller simpler game than sprawling epics like Dragon Age but with the same sort of game play and in an unusual genre setting.

reviewText:
This is by far one of the hardest games I've ever played. The reason for that is the game play mechanics. For example there were many times when I preformed an attack on the enemy and then tried to moved out of the way but then I could not continue moving  until the enemy performed a hit and I have died a great many times because of this. Your sidekicks are useless and you can only have one with you at a time. They almost without fail get knocked out early one in a fight leaving at time three or more enemies for you to deal with. As far as I can tell they are static characters with no way to upgrade their skills or weapons. This game will ♥♥♥♥ you off  be ready for that


The story is okay and maybe you'll continue your character in the upcoming sequel and maybe they will fix the Issues that this game had. Also the game is short.

reviewText: I got it for pennies in a 20-game bundle, and its actually better than some of the games I was really after, but still one to doubt.  At normal price I'd draw a breath and suggest its not worth wasting time on.  It may keep you occupied, but it doesn't amuse or entertain. It's a bit clunky, there's a lot of scenery repetition, and only a shallow assortment of NPC faces, and uses a non-standard distribution of key assigments that makes learning it a matter of frustration.  But you do get used it its quirks after a trime, enough to realise its a simple, basic story that could do with a deal of creative input.  The game engine is used in many similar games, so its a bit like the Spiders company can turn these out at whim.  Once you have a game's coding set in stone, all you need do is change the graphics and presto, a brand new game.  Looks like that's what they've done here.  A game made for the sake of making a game methinks.

reviewText:
Overall good.   Combat mechanics are pretty polished, and the role playing system is pretty comprehensive.  The story is simple but not too bad.

It does have some gameflow issues though.   There's one quest early on involving a guard where if you solve his side quest or kill him too soon, he won't be able to help you with another quest required to progress.

The game is also a bit repetitive.   Completing each main quests consistently respawns the map enemies that you defeated previously.  Which wouldn't be so bad each main quest wasn't always on the other side of the map from the one you just completed.  That means you have to slog through all of them again.   If it wasn't for all the repetitive fighting, this game would be quite short.

reviewText:
this is a good game.

ill start with that. the combat is reminiscent of assassins creed though it has the difference that instead of group 1v1 anyone can attack you whenever they like which allows the game to be more challenging. there is a basic crafting and upgrade system in the game which allows for a variety of different armors and weapons to be used though there are really just one set that can be chosen for the endgame as they are just better then the others.

the story i wont say is the most original, war prisoner leads rebelion against oppresive government with different paths to take to lead to that ultimate end. you will also have choices within each section that will affect how the story is told in the cutscenes and at the ending.

the game has an interesting art style and while it does look good at times it is inconsistant. most character based items and cloths have good textures with a good deal of detail. however some environmental textures are rather low res so they dont look good.

the total game time is around 8 hours and personally i cant replay the game but i do know people that would be able to make different choices for different outcomes.

if i could get 8 hours out of cod for 20 bucks just singleplayer i would multiplayer doesnt matter to me so thats my choice.

reviewText:
I can't take this anymore. Slow and uncomfortable fighting mechanism, and frigid Innocence(I hate this guy so much, I wish there were possibility to murder him) ruined my experience.

I'll probably take some time to murder someone in other game I am comfortable with, and lower my anger about this game, then try again with it. I wanted to play it because before release it looked promising and I watched video and read a lot about it. After trying the game first time I was disappointed and decided to wait for some patches or something.

If you want to play this game, be prepared for
* People on streets stearing at one place for hours, freezed in one pose without any movement.
* Small boulders on the ground normal people can walk through, but in this game you cannot.
* Any furniture or crates are bound to eachother and to ground/walls with some god powers, you will never be able to move them.
* Walking NPC(Any NPC, actually) will never notice you and will always try to walk through. Also you will not be able to interrupt their stearing contest.
* Your hero is not able to go on any stairs with very rare exceptions(quest or crossroads). So you cannot use crates or stairs in fight.

To sum up, this game is dead and feels scipted, not alive it pretends to be. Killing someone you will never feel you killed a bad guy or saved good guy, it will be another scripted thing you indifferent to.

reviewText: Surely an easily over-looked and/or underrated game. Mars: War Logs offers everything an open-world/RPG gamer can want in a game. From customizing clothing, weapons, and fighting style to dialog choices that effect your outcomes in the game. If I were to rank this game I would give it 4.5/5 stars, the .5 being for less open space exploring and more like the feeling of a series of hallways you must run through, but despite the maps everything else in the game picks up the slack. What sells me personally the most is this game offers force powers in a post-apocalyptic theme, I couldn't ask for more.

reviewText: Good ideas, bad implementation.  Not very pc friendly on the controls. Graphically, the game is moderately appealling but thats about where it ends.  The combat is sluggish and the story seems to be missing something.  Overall, the game didn't leave much of a good impression on me personally, hence the little play time I did put into it. I may go back and trudge through it some more to see if it does get better, but there are so many better gaming options out there for the same price, I just don't think that will happen.  I would recommend passing on this one for now, but maybe down the road, the devs can actually put something better out there for this game, making it worth the price of admission.

reviewText: Mars War Logs starts with promise but goes nowhere. It seems for the first couple of hours that it will turn into 'Red Faction Witcher' but after those first couple hours you've seen most everything the game has to offer and nothing special ever develops. Quests are extremely basic 'fetch item and come back' for the most part, and the story simply doesn't get interesting. The voice acting is a combination of poor" and "absolutely terrible". The combat is tedious no matter what difficulty you play at. I got bored and quit several hours before the end of the game and I rarely do that with story based RPGs. A very linear
recommended: mediocre RPG with very little to offer and not a single memorable moment."

reviewText: Mars: War Logs wants to be a Bioware game; a sprawling epic with sharp and nuanced action-RPG mechanics, full of big moral choices, set in a well-defined sci-fi world. Unfortunately those kinds of games are really expensive, so we get janky-yet-serviceable gameplay accompanying us through a story that could've either used a few more or a few less edits, in a sci-fi world that was clerly well thought-out, although poorly communicated.\n\nBut if it was 'Bioware big', it would blow most of Bioware's catalog out of the water. If you give it a chance to try, you can see the seeds of a fantastic game that just didn't get the care and money it needed. The end result is a decent enough game, worth picking up on special, but couldn't reach its potential.

reviewText:
I definitely recommend the game. I got it on sale for $5, and after 1.5 hours I already feel I got enough fun for the money—and the game has only just begun. So, I think even the $17 for the game is well worth the price.

If you go in with right expectatoions into this game, you can definitely enjoy it. It delivers just what a $17 game should deliver; don't compare it to those that go for $40-$60.

There's no jumping in the game and you do occasionally bump into an invisible wall. There are some really grotesque looking people and I often want to find out what had happened to them, but alas, they just ignore you and there's no option to talk to them. Some characters stand in your way, [intentionally?] blocking your way. They're like furniture—no interaction with you at all—which feels lazy and lame on the part of developers.

What irks me the most is the UI. Every time you pick up loot or ransack a corpse, you get a popup message telling you what you found, and you gotta click OK" to close it. This really should've been a brief message at the bottom instead. Quests

reviewText:
A lot of potential

Even though the combat can get repetitive if you don't change your approach and the crafting system is lacking the proper menu's mechanics the game feels like a real adventure on the desolate, burnt and cyberpunkish set up in Mars: Wars Logs.

The story may not be the best around but it fills perferctly the game and the voice acting is superb in many aspects. The sound score is not any bad either.

reviewText:
Another great RPG from Spiders developer. They have the atmosphere, good storyline and graphic of a war prison on Mars.

EDIT: after playing another game from Spiders studio, Bound by flame, which I don't like really, I can see even more why this game is better then ordinary - the main character is really well developed - his voice does fit - it sounds like someone who went through a lot of things, his story keeps you interested that you don't know it really, so the whole time you are tryring to uncover more about his background.

Also probably because the developer had this idea for longer time on his mind, he really thought out all the details of life on Mars - people, their outfits, where they would live-every part of the city is different, everything.

Also crafting, weapons and music/background noise adds to this atmosphere.

The only thing that holds this game back is limitations of its engine and capacity of a small game studio.

reviewText:
Mars: War Logs is an odd chimera. The graphics aren't bad for an indie game, and the concepts behind it are fairly solid and intriguing. Unfortunately, there are a lot of technical details that mar the experience, but overall it's a game worth buying - if you're getting it cheap.

Combat can (and likely will) be frustrating until you learn all the right tricks. You'll always be outnumbered, often four or five to one, and most foes need to be hit a dozen times before they'll fall - while just five or six hits will often kill you. Expect to spend a lot of time manically rolling from side to side as you try to evade them, or invest heavily in explosives to end combat as quickly as possible.

The voice acting is passable, but crude. A number of the voice actors adopt 'silly' voices as they leapfrog from character to character, and several of the actors actually say something entirely different from what the subtitles are saying. Although the main character's voice is decent enough, I found myself often skipping through awkwardly delivered (and profanity-riddled) lines with greater regularity as the game progressed.

There are moral choices present in the game, but they're generally very basic. Do you want to murder these people for a few extra dollar? Well then that's evil, and it will be reflected in your reputation. Do you NOT want to murder these people? Oh, well then you're a decent guy. Congrats. It rarely gets much more in-depth then that, though.

On the plus side, though, both the skills and the crafting system are fairly well done. Every skill you unlock gives you a very tangible benefit or ability, making it difficult to choose which one you want. Crafting is almost required to progress, and acts as an invaluable aid, both for crafting 'one-use' items like grenades or health injectors and for modifying your basic weapons and armor.

All in all, I'd give Mars: War Logs a 7 out of 10. Worth the buy, if you're getting it for ten dollars or less.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It was difficult to decide whether to recommend this game or not. As a summary, I would say this is a game for sci-fi fans that prioritize story over game play and are not afraid to sacrifise game-play and graphic looks to delve into a slightly unusual universe and an OK story.

What was good in this game: a) The story was in addition to dialogue and cut scenes told through diary entries, which helped keep up with what is going on. b) Good character and location descriptions. c) Technomancy replaced magic here, which is an interesting skill to master and play with.

What could have been better: a) The game's graphics are very outdated, there are not many details to look at both when it comes to pure graphical looks, and immersive details. b) Almost all side-quests involve doing something and returning for reward: there is simply too much running from A to B, back to A and B again. If the world was more immersive, it might be more fun this way, but now it can be a little bit boring. A good thing is it doesn't take too much time to run like that. c) Voice acting could have been better in certain places to make the story more immersive.

Neutral points to note: a) The game is majorly linnear, with a few exceptions. b) Fighting is basic and not very complex, but made more fun through Technomancy skill tree. c) The world is limited to the player, there are invisible borders here and there, but mostly there is walking in corridors between structures and rock walls.

I chose to recommend this game, mostly because of the story and the way it was presented through diary entries and descriptions. Although the story itself isn't very immersive or more than averagely engaging, it kept me interested enough to finish the game. However, I would like to note that the story and universe they built in this game had several parts which would have been very interesting to learn more about. Simply put, there are some pretty interesting ideas, but it is a pity the game never explores them (more deeply).

So try this if you aren't bothered by above mentioned negative and neutral points.

reviewText: Clearly a low budget game, but I thoroughly enjoyed it nonetheless. The story was very interesting and kept me playing through somewhat tedious quests. The voice acting could have been better in some places and often didn't match the on-screen text, but it didn't detract from the playability or enjoyment, in my opinion. I liked the variety of melee weaponry and wardrobe, as well as the crafting aspects and skill trees. I would have liked at least one more type of gun, however, since there was only one (that I could find). Also love that it offered full controller support, always a big plus for me. I think a DLC or two could add a lot to this game and I would buy in a heartbeat. Overall, I really enjoyed Mars: War Logs and I hope to see more polished games from this dev.

reviewText:
Everything is fine about the game except for the combat system. Generic characters, graphics, skill trees, and storyline. Exactly what you'd expect from a publisher of this size.

But the combat is worse than the ME3 ending. It's like it was designed to crawl under your skinand infuriate you. They throw multiple enemies at you in choke points, give you extremely limited blocking and rolling abilities, and interrupt all your actions everytime you're hit.

Oh you wanted to roll out of the way? Well this guy punched you three seconds ago and you're still staggered.

Abysmal.

reviewText:
Mars: War Logs is a cyberpunk rpg in which you fight the a corporation (or is a government?) called Abundance because they are the people that attack you.  Also you fight thugs and mole-things.

Gameplay - It's pretty lacking.  The only time you interact with the world is when you dig through the trash or talk to a merchant.  There are also side quests to do, but they're not interesting and don't really have any affect on the environment.  It's like played bioware games, thought they ROCKED, and then didn't realize what they liked about them.  The combat's also pretty underwhelming.  It's a brawler (in the vein of Sleeping Dogs, just without the combos or useful interface) which would be fine, except for this terrible ability every enemy has; the ability to not take damage. Every so often, usually when you're doing well, they'll choose to jump back and avoid all of your damage.

This is a pretty big deal since there's no way to counter it (even if they're already against a wall) and you're usually against a large group of competant enemies.  Choosing to attack an enemy is a risky decision since they can all suddenly start tearing through you at any moment.  It's not even an issue of difficulty, it's an issue of poor design.  You're forced to spend most of each encounter rolling around waiting for your technopowers to recharge

Story - I feel like there could have been a really cool story here.  From what I gathered, it's based on a cool idea of corporate warfare on an unforgiving planet and the effects that can have on a population.  The problem is that the game does NOTHING with any of this.  It's like they start the game right after the end of a really cool game.  No part of the story is really explained beyond these are the bad guys because just trust me" moments.  I mean
date: the whole first act of the game seems to only happen because of the main character's impatience.   I actually had to stop playing at the end of the second act because I was given a choice to make and realized that I had NO idea what anyone was talking about or trying to accomplish.\n\nActing - I feel like it's important to be forgiving here; how many indie studios could talented voice actors? It's entirely possible that it was just the developers.  To their credit

This game lacked any and all effort. Everything felt unfinished, rushed, or ignored.

reviewText:
The gameplay in this game basically consists of wading through a leper colony whacking people with a lead pipe. There are guns, bombs and mines in the game, but they are inferior to THE PIPE. There is electric magic, but the pipe still wins.

The typical gameplay: you go through a corridor, ugly crippled people sit by the wall and look at you, a enemy soldier appears at the other end, you rush to him and beat him down with your trusty pipe. Then go to the next corridor and repeat.

There is a crafting system too, you can add a leather grip to your pipe, and tape a tooth of giant lizard to the other end to increase its DPS.

The graphics is ugly, but this meshes well with the general atmosphere of lost war, ecologic disaster and general desperation, and almost seems intentional.

The game works, there are no bugs, you can complete the quests and advance along the plot line, but ... you know... this endless pipe fencing is just not fun.

I recall many games that looked a bit like this from my youth. Linear, slightly blocky textures, lots of running about and terse dialogue. Even the voice acting reminds me of those games, and the 8 hours of this I played reflect the nostalgia trip I was on. However, the lack of any real depth just had too great an impact, and I found myself dreading loading it up. That's when you know it's time to move this from the pile of shame in to plain old not interested" category.

reviewText:
I played this game, and recorded a Lets Play of it. you can find the playlist at https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLNzEgKaq7dj7X35FCBrdFDHtcGcAWEA0Z It is currently still airing and will be completed early 2015.

Likes:
-General lore of the world and setting
-The graphics, and bringing the world to life.
-The storyline

Dislikes:
-Companions are basically just cannon fodder, and nothing more.
-Combat system feels lacking, just smash buttons until they die.
-The difficulty is hendered by the combat system, making the game way harder than it should be at times, simply because of the way combat works. Then the next instance the game is laughably easy.
-The boss mobs in the game are basically just tanks that take more time, and less though to beat. Hit them, then evade.


Overall I had a lot of fun playing the game, and enjoyed the story and character development.

reviewText:
While the game description is completely wrong and possibly describing another game entirely it is a very enjoyable game.

It is not a cyberpunk game. Even though cyberpunk is very hard to classify and provide any rules to make it so, this game is not cyberpunk. post apocalytic, yes. and though it is said to be on Mars any planet would have done as earth was mentioned once or twice in passing and could have been completely left out. This could have taken place on Earth and it would not have made any diffference if the mentioning of being on Mars was left out.

The description also states water drives a company war. No mention of attaining water is present, only the acquiring of power lost since the cataclysm. So, no part of the description is accurate. Except maybe the part of being a RPG. RPG-Lite, yes. With a very basic and limited crafting system to upgrade weapons and armor you can still have some variety in how you upgrade these items. Basic but nice.

The Feats are not that creative but the Skills and the associated trees give a decent variety to choose from and also provide some replayability. this is good because to get 100% acheivement you will have to replay twice. once on the second hardest difficulty and once on the hardest. you will also need to choose either the resistance or a general trying to overthrow the government. different choice will give a different ending which is good.

After about 18 hours played once through I will at some point revisit the game. Not to get the 100% but because I enjoyed it. I didn't expect to because as other reviews state it suffers from Bad to very, very, very bad camera controls along with some questionable voice acting and written dialogue. a few times I laughed at how bad it was but there are some characters that are voiced awesome and have great dialogue to make up for the bad ones.

All that said I would tell anyone about this game and how surprisingly good it is. Maybe the secret to my enjoyment was expecting a horrible experience. Far from my expectations. I look Forward to the next game I just learned is entitled Technomancer and hopefully will be out soon.

reviewText:
Despite many negative reviews from critics, and despite some flaws, for the most part I enjoyed this game and thought it was solid. The story takes place in a gritty, dystopian, almost post-apoc setting and spans 3 chapters. There are a lot of sidequests and character interactions, and the game tends to alternate between big open areas and linear levels, which in my opinion provided a nice change pace.

Perhaps what I liked the most was the levelling and the combat. The fighting was incredibly fun, a little awkward at first, but easy to get used to. And the customization of your weapon and armour is great. You get to find various tools and crafting parts that you can use on your gear to give it additional bonuses of your choice. The levelling had 3 different mastery trees - combat, renegade (support abilities like healing and stealth), and technomancy (electrical powers). The levelling happened very frequently, which was great too, since you didn't have to wait for ages to get to the skills you've had your eyes on.

The story and setting are pretty interesting. I personally found chapters 1 and 2 to be brilliant, but chapter 3 fell flat on its face. It almost felt as though the game was rushed at the end. What was most interesting perhaps is how at the end of chapter 2 you get a choice of split paths to join one of the 2 factions, which changes some things in chapter 3, but ultimately you end up visiting the exact same locations regardless of which faction you go with. The premise of split paths for the final chapter is fantastic, but the execution resulted in a diluted experience. Going with the Resistance at least was a half-decent attempt at a conclusion that presented some more moral choices down the line. But going with the general felt like it was added into the game at the very last minute just for the sake of having this split path feature.

The game also had 3 romance options in it, but this too felt rather lacking and devoid of much dialogue. A few other NPCs felt like they should've gotten more screen time than they actually did, like the bounty hunter friend of the main character. But apart from that, most characters were rather interesting.

Overall I'd recommend this game. It's a decent sci-fi cyberpunk RPG and I was immersed for the duration of playing it, even going as far as trying out both story paths for its somewhat disappointing conclusion.

reviewText:
Mars: War Logs is a game I really wanted to like.
But it just fails to come together as a cohesive whole.

And that's the tragic part, this game has so many parts that should be amazing but every step of the way there are little hiccups that bring it down.
The game, for me, felt drawn out by bad loading screens as I climbed up or down from items, cringed at horrible dialog, wondered as recruitable NPCs went from bloody vengance to being my friend after a single line of dialog, was gobsmacked as the game forgot to tell me crucial plot important details, and the combat never gained the depth one would have liked.

I wanted to like this game, I wanted it to succeed, but it didn't.
I hold the greatest hope that these people will try again and their next product will be a polished RPG worthy of great praise from all the lessons learned from this one.
But I'm afraid I can't recommend it to anybody.

reviewText: I cant really say that there was to much that stood out to me in Mars War Logs. I had hoped this game would fill a small chunk of time with a decent RPG, and I wasn't expecting much really. However, I was expecting something better than this. The game itself doesn't look all too pretty, even on highest settings. The voice acting is really, really bad, and the characters themselves are really hard to take seriously (Of course the kid named Innocence has to almost get ♥♥♥♥♥ by a guy named Fatty...). When you have a character that is so driven to kill you that she abandoned her order, almost get herself killed, then gets saved by you and realizing you're not the monster she thought (with little to no insistence from yourself) you may think that yes, she may decide to join with you. What I don't expect is for her to wake up, spend 30 seconds in your presence (that's not an exaggeration), then offer to paint the taint with you since you are her new mentor. It wholeheartedly broke any respect for future character development I had for this game. Moving on, the back story is very poorly conveyed, the description states that water is scarce and wars are being fought over it, but I never heard mention of water once. The crafting system seems minimal, and the levels themselves feel like they are empty, even though NPC's meander about before you. I will say the combat system does feel similar to the Witcher, but isn't nearly as fluid or responsive. All in all I wasn't impressed. It's not a terrible, mind numbing experience, but it didn't hold my attention long enough to finish it. And to be honest that rarely happens.

reviewText:
This gem seems to be overlooked by many.  I have myself ditched it for a few months after playing it for 30-40 minutes.  It is slow at first and due to the small size of the team that made the game is rough around the edges: graphics may not be AAA grade, lips are not stynced, dialogues may not be 100% but once you give it a chance the story gets REALLY good!
Combat is well made, it resembles a bit Assasin's Creed where you have your spells/combos/ranged attacks but most of the fight takes place in close combat.

Im' certain to give it one mroe replay to see how the story unfolds when I try out some different choices for all the quests...

reviewText:
I just beat the game 14 hours in.I really like this game. It is a budget game so don't expect high production graphics or good voice acting. It is a RPG so leveling up and skills are done really good,
The game has few moral choices throughout the game which can change the story very dramatically. The sidequest are done quite nicely and actually has link to the story.

The story is really interesting for such small game it is not vast but it is well written.
I didn't face any bugs but I have few problems with some of the games design choices like the NPC dies very easily so you have to work hard to keep them.

So for a 20$ price point it is WORTH IT.Please if you like Witcher type games get this game.

reviewText: This is a good and solid adventure third person adventure shooter/rpg with leveling.  It reminds me a bit of Rage" but is much better.  Solid and interesting story from start to finish - which is also it's strongest point.  You start out as a prisoner of war on what i guess is a terraformed planet Mars.  You hardly know what the hell is going on or who you really are at first.  Your first mission is to try to get out of the prison.  As you play along you learn why you ended up there
date: who is fighting and why.  Who is the enemy?\nYour decisions in game have an impact á la the mass effect games.\nInterestingly Mars:war logs got bad reviews from big official game review magazines
recommended: BUT it got good reviews from the gamers which is what matters to me.  Look it up for yourself on metacritic.\nAnyway it took me 21 hrs from start to finish
hoursPlayed: and i thoroughly enjoyed it!"

reviewText: I cant really say that there was to much that stood out to me in Mars War Logs. I had hoped this game would fill a small chunk of time with a decent RPG, and I wasn't expecting much really. However, I was expecting something better than this. The game itself doesn't look all too pretty, even on highest settings. The voice acting is really, really bad, and the characters themselves are really hard to take seriously (Of course the kid named Innocence has to almost get ♥♥♥♥♥ by a guy named Fatty...). When you have a character that is so driven to kill you that she abandoned her order, almost get herself killed, then gets saved by you and realizing you're not the monster she thought (with little to no insistence from yourself) you may think that yes, she may decide to join with you. What I don't expect is for her to wake up, spend 30 seconds in your presence (that's not an exaggeration), then offer to paint the taint with you since you are her new mentor. It wholeheartedly broke any respect for future character development I had for this game. Moving on, the back story is very poorly conveyed, the description states that water is scarce and wars are being fought over it, but I never heard mention of water once. The crafting system seems minimal, and the levels themselves feel like they are empty, even though NPC's meander about before you. I will say the combat system does feel similar to the Witcher, but isn't nearly as fluid or responsive. All in all I wasn't impressed. It's not a terrible, mind numbing experience, but it didn't hold my attention long enough to finish it. And to be honest that rarely happens.

reviewText:
3/10
This game should be called 'Mars: Evasive Rolls and Gophering'  because that is virtually all you will be doing.
Things you can do in Mars: War Logs, listed by frequency:

Sick Rolls: You will die almost immediately without them. 90% of your battle strategy will be somersaults, side rolls, and back rolls).

Getting things for apparent invalids: Everyone needs something, and, yes, it is on the other side of the bland and lifeless map.

Listen to mind-numbing dialog and fifth-rate voice acting: The mish mash of accents and hammed-up acting is intense.

Sell all your items one by one: You know how most games allow you to sell items two, or even three, at a time? Not Mars: War Logs. You must sell everything one by one, even if you have fifty of them. Enjoy!

Crafting objects that are way more expensive then just buying them: To craft a health injection costs 20 serum, to buy one costs 8. Do the math.

Putting sick plates on your dusty clothes: Now you can look like an awesome post-apocalyptic warrior, or maybe you can look like Kevin Costner in The Postman.

Actually fighting: When you aren't busy gophering, crafting, and getting lulled into a rage-coma by the silly acting and storytelling, you can beat enemies with improvised weapons. Yes, we are far into the future, but due to apparent reason guns, laser swords, and fun weapons don't exist in this sparse world. You get to beat up on your enemy with light fixtures and mole creature bones.

Pros of Mars: War Logs: You will be momentarily distracted from all the evil in this world by this catastrophe. You will get to practice your digital gymnastic skills (except for jumping, because why jump over things when you can roll right past them?).

Cons: Playing Mars: War Logs is a lot like playing Solitare. It's basically a way to tell your friends and family that you are exceptionally bored and have nothing on your plate at the moment. It's inviting people to give you a menial task to do, much like the NPCs in Mars: War Logs. Don't let it happen.

reviewText:
I was excited about this game at first, but after playing it for a few hours i have grown very frustrated with this game.

First the story was hard to get into, and I didn't feel as if I was being engaged, I didn't feel a reason to care about anything that was happening in the world.

Second battle mechanics were very anoying, being ganged up on by six enemies at once was tedious and a task, being unable to aim with the nail gun was aslo annoying and would have been a good addition to the game play. blocking always seemed to be impossible for me and it seemed as if every other move for the A.I. was a knockbak hit.

Third the upgrade and loot system are broken, and i felt that i wasn't given enough options, and i felt that i wasn't rewarded for defeating six enemies.

The game looked nice though, i would have prefered more diversity, but otherwise the creatures looked cool and were creatively made.

All in all i would say pass on this game .

reviewText: This is a rough one to thumbs up or down, I wish there was a neutral option (pay attention Steam!).  The game is pretty decent, and once you figure out the combat problems and techniques (yes, problems), it's a decent play.  However, the ovewhelmingly big issue is technomancy.  Everyone in the game world talks about technomancers like they are gods.  You turn out to be one and can use these powers.  Except you will NEVER be able to use these powers.  They are amazingly slow, so there is no way you can ever use them in a fight, other than if there is a single opponent who is focused on your companion, and at that point you may as well just club them instead.  They missed a huge opportunity with this massive design flaw to allow you to play different styles of character.  This continues through the other combat options as well, they simply are not designe well enough to allow for anything other than one style of play, when there could be 3 easily.  So, if you ignore technomacny entirely, never waste skill points on it, never try to use it, just focus on grenades, sneaking, and melee as your main points of combat (the occaisional trap and nail gun attack are fine too), then it's a decent play.  Unfortunately the other major flaw is that side quests never show objective markers like main quests, so that's pretty frustrating as well.  Get it on 60% off or more sale, it's not worth paying full price, and there are probably more enjoyable games to blow time on.

reviewText:
It's hard whether to reccomend Mars: War Logs or not.

The reason for this being it is flawed. It's not subtly flawed, it's in your face flawed. From the cringe inducing script, the abysmal voice acting, the weak plot, the dated graphics and the subpar combat it's a shambles.

Or it should be a shambles, Mars: War Logs has a certain charm to it. I particulary liked the enviroment which, even with dated graphics, sucked me into the world. The rusted shacks, the red mars sky/floor, the seedy corridors, the trash all over the place. It really does convince me that this world is in a turmoil. Another thing I liked are the characters involved, although they could've been much better with more fleshing out and a better script. I can't really make myself symphathise with them much because there isn't enough time spent with them. I'm asked to make a choice between two groups of people after meeting with them once? That is poor.

Now onto the gameplay since it is a video game. The combat reminds me of The Witcher, so naturally it's enjoyable. It isn't nearly as polished as The Witcher's combat but then again it is hard to top that. The crafting was a fun edition to the game as well, however there's limited choice of materials and there aren't as many items to craft as I hoped there would be sadly. The reputation system is nice, be a ♥♥♥♥ and you can intimidate people is something I liked from Mass Effect so I'm glad to see it here. The skill tree system is great, again it's like The Witcher, and there's many skills to upgrade which means there will be some replayability available since you can't possibly upgrade them all. There's not much questing in this game, so it's a short affair despite being an RPG. The world, whilst great, isn't nearly large enough which again means there's a larger limit on game time. If the developers had made larger areas and filled it with more quests this game could easily add a few more hours onto playtime.

I have no complaints about the music, but there's nothing to really compliment either. It just does it's job without standing out.

In conclusion, I'm going to reccomend this game. It may be heavily flawed, but for the price I bought it for £2.99 I felt it was worth the money. So pick it up on sale, or if you're an RPG fanatic who's got the itch for a new game pick it up now.

reviewText: Having a blast with this game. Kind of a mix between Mass Effect (character dialog choices and reputation system), Fallout (loot, overall setting and crafting) and Skyrim (real time combat + dodges and parries). The level design leaves a lot to be desired and even the updated V/O dialog is still not great. But the atmosphere, the story, the characters, the combat, the crafting are all very interesting and fun. Also it's not the longest game, but at 1/3rd the price of most new games, I can't really complain. Hope to see a bigger sequel from the same developers.

reviewText: Mars: War Logs is definitely not a perfect game, it has its share of flaws, but what game doesn't? I found this game to be incredibly good, the story, the characters, and the setting are all very compelling from the first scene, to the end credits. While not an incredibly long game it's well worth playing, and I intend to play through it at least a couple more times. Mars: War Logs is definitely worth the price and I recommend it to anyone looking for a quick, compelling, sci-fi RPG.

reviewText:
I got a small amount of entertainment out of this low budget RPG. The story is pretty barebones, the characters are very hit-and-miss (especially their names, with one of the main characters being called Innocence!) and the graphics looks like something out of the Playstation 2 era. It took me about seven hours to complete and I completed one or two of the side quests, otherwise it was only main/story quests all the way through.

You're playing as Roy (his real name being Temperance) and you start in a prison camp where the goal is to... simply break out. After that it's time to get revenge on... errr... the government. And I can't really remember why... that speaks for itself, it has gone about ten minutes since I completed the game and I can't remember one of the bigger plot points of the game. Well done...

Sure, I bought the game for about $4 and that's not a very high price. One of the better things with the game was the combat... which was rather repetetive but at least action-filled. Hit two-three times, roll to dodge, hit two-three times, use a nailgun or a spell" - repeat. But
date: the biggest (and it looks like the only one) "pro" I have is that now I want to play some more RPGs... but one with more interesting characters and better story this time around. The Witcher? Dragon Age: Origins? Who knows?"

reviewText:
I played for 15 hours on normal, completing the main quest with one ending, and the majority of the side quests. I used the XBOX 360 controller to play the game.

I can only recommend the game on sale, and if you don’t have any high expectations. You might be disappointed otherwise, like I was. I was more disappointed in the plot and characters as I got nearer to the end of the game.

Mars: War Logs (MWL) starts off great but will eventually fall flat and dull, with boring characters, story, and environments. RPG elements are great, and combat gets more interesting if you invest the points wisely. MWL looks good on top that helps immersion, unfortunately on closer inspection npcs and the environment look rough around the edges. MWL has a very linear corridor setup for you to travel around, and visually the game gets very repetitive.

MWL does start with an interesting story, and characters. Mars itself has a robust background that really helps create immersion in the game, the same can be said for the characters, but it doesn’t last. The story feels uninspired nearer the end of the game, and characters feel rushed, flat, and placed to connect the plot. This is a shame because Spiders have done a really good job in creating the universe you play in, they just couldn’t hold it up.

Your introduction to the protagonist, Roy Temperance is a little odd, as he doesn't react to the situation he’s in. He just stands there in silence, and the gang leader he’s confronting has a one way conversation with him. I understand that maybe the reason for this was to make Roy a blank canvas, so you could shape his personality with the conversation lines you pick. However they missed a good opportunity to introduce the conversation mechanic. You can also further shape Roy by either abandoning fallen enemies or killing them at the end of a fight, the payoff is more serum, serum is the game currency as well as a craftable for medicine.

Like a lot of action games the fighting doesn’t get interesting till you unlock certain skills that compliment your play style. The same could be said for MWL, because when you unlock the technomancer skill set, the combat is a lot more fun. You can plan your skill advancements by looking at the locked skills, this really helped gain the skills I wanted on level up.

For everything the combat does right, it does something wrong as well, but at least it gives you options. You can go solo or go along with a side kick. You can control your buddy’s fighting style with defensive/attack nearest/ranged/or same as, but you can’t share items and tell them to use them or certain attacks, also you can’t heal them. Not being able to heal your party member will mean that they could fall during the fight. Mashing buttons won’t help you either, this will end up queuing the next selection while the current action is played out, a little thought and planning is vital to fights. There is the option to go in stealthy and hide enemies to avoid alerting others, your success may depend on your skill unlocks. Combat isn’t helped by bad camera angles, that can have you fighting off screen till it resets or you move it.

From an RPG aspect a lot of game mechanics and details were added that really benefit the game. You can craft upgrades for your melee weapon or clothing, your conversation choices will affect the person you become and the reactions by npcs. Levelling up will give you skill points to use for combat, and in the trait selection. The trait selection offers an additional boost to non combat things such as looting and crafting. Cutscenes can be skipped as well. All these little elements enrich the gameplay and were thought out by an experienced dev team with gaming experience.

Visually MWL looks good on top then degrades the further down you go. Roy Temperance, has a lot of detail and looks good. However thing start to look a little worse when you get to npcs and the environment itself. MWL really needed some variety in how it looks, the change in environment was occasional, but still bland at best.

Hopefully one daySpiders will  revisit Mars, they really do have an impressive backstory with a lot of potential to do more with, especially with the technomancy.

reviewText:
I got a small amount of entertainment out of this low budget RPG. The story is pretty barebones, the characters are very hit-and-miss (especially their names, with one of the main characters being called Innocence!) and the graphics looks like something out of the Playstation 2 era. It took me about seven hours to complete and I completed one or two of the side quests, otherwise it was only main/story quests all the way through.

You're playing as Roy (his real name being Temperance) and you start in a prison camp where the goal is to... simply break out. After that it's time to get revenge on... errr... the government. And I can't really remember why... that speaks for itself, it has gone about ten minutes since I completed the game and I can't remember one of the bigger plot points of the game. Well done...

Sure, I bought the game for about $4 and that's not a very high price. One of the better things with the game was the combat... which was rather repetetive but at least action-filled. Hit two-three times, roll to dodge, hit two-three times, use a nailgun or a spell" - repeat. But
date: the biggest (and it looks like the only one) "pro" I have is that now I want to play some more RPGs... but one with more interesting characters and better story this time around. The Witcher? Dragon Age: Origins? Who knows?"

reviewText:
It's like a bioware rpg (jade Empire mostly) with a 10th of the budget, a 20th of the charm and none of the redeeming qualities.

To elaborate (or basically repeat myself), it has what you would expect from an rpg in 2013: a story, a real-time combat system, some companions, some choices and a few consequences, but the game never excels in any of these or gives you any reason why you would want to play this over any bioware games (yes, even those ones).

Wait until The Witcher 2 is cheaper than a fast food boxed meal again if you're one of those weirdos who doesn't have it yet (assuming you want a game containing a story, a real-time combat system, some choices and some consequences).
